nodes.body:
There is an ancient morphological verb opposition in Tibetan which corresponds to a causative derivation. This morphological opposition has generated verb pairs: a “causative” verb, both transitive and volitional, is derived[1] from a basic verb which is usually both intransitive and non-volitional. This basic verb stem is referred to here as the “resultative” form.

The two verbs that comprise each pair are phonetically very close, and in most cases their pronunciation differs only in terms of tone or aspiration.

The causative derivation is essential in many Tibeto-Burman languages as well as in Classical Tibetan (with over 200 verb pairs) and in some archaic dialects of Amdo, but in Central Tibetan and in the Standard Spoken language, it applies only to a few dozen verbs.

  • བཅག་ “To break” (causative), ཆག་ “To break” (resultative)
  • སྙལ་ “To lay” (causative), ཉལ་ “To lie” (resultative)
  • བཀག་ “To stop” (causative), འགག་ “To stop” (resultative)
  • བསླངས་ “To raise” (causative), ལང་ “To rise” (resultative)
  • གདོར་ “To scatter” (causative), འཐོར་ “To scatter, be scattered” (resultative)
  • སྐོལ་ “To boil” (causative), འཁོལ་ “To boil” (resultative)
  • སྐོར་ “To stir, turn” (causative), འཁོར་ “To stir, turn” (resultative)
  • བཏོན་ “To take out” (causative), དོན་ “To go out” (resultative)
  • ཕབ་ “To bring down, take down” (causative), འབབ་ “To descend, get down” (resultative)
  • སྒྲོལ་ “To free” (causative), གྲོལ་ “To be freed” (resultative)
  • དབྲལ་ “To tear” (causative), རལ་ “To tear” (resultative)
  • བཅད་ “To cut” (causative), ཆད་ “To be cut” (resultative)

Compared to the basic resultative stem, the causative always has an additional argument corresponding to an intentional agent performing the action.

If the resultative is intransitive, the causative is transitive.

If the resultative is transitive, the causative is ditransitive (see the examples below).

It emerges from the above that all the causative verbs are transitive and volitional, since they imply an agent is intentionally performing an action on an object or a patient. Resultative verbs are usually intransitive and non-volitional.

  • ཐག་པ་ཆད་སོང་། Resultative: “The rope broke.” (The rope got cut by itself, without any intentional cause.)
  • ཁོང་གིས་ཐག་པ་བཅད་སོང་། Causative: “He cut the rope.” (An agent cut the rope intentionally.)
  • ཤེལ་སྒོ་ཆག་བཞག Resultative: “The pane broke.” (The pane broke by itself, without any intentional cause.)
  • སྤུ་གུ་ཚོས་ཤེལ་སྒོ་བཅག་སོང་། Causative: “The children broke the pane.” (The children intentionally broke the pane.)
  • མ་ཎི་འཁོར་བསྡད་བཞག Resultative: “The prayer wheel is still spinning.” (Nobody is now making it spin, it is spinning by itself.)
  • སྨོ་ལགས་ཀྱིས་མ་ཎི་བསྐོར་སོང་། Resultative: “The old lady has turned the prayer wheel.” (An agent has intentionally turned the wheel.)
  • ཡི་གེ་རེལ་བཞག Resultative: “The letter is torn.”
  • ཁོང་གིས་ཡི་གེ་དབྲལ་པ་རེད། Causative: “He tore the letter (intentionally).”

Certain resultative intransitive verbs may, in some cases, allow the use of an unintentional agent.

  • ཁོང་གིས་ཡི་གེ་རལ་བཞག Resultative: “He tore the letter (unintentionally).”
  • སྤུ་གུ་ཚོས་ཤེལ་སྐོ་ཆག་བཞག Resultative: “The children broke the pane (unintentionally).”

However, this construction is rather rare in Standard Spoken Tibetan. Some speakers prefer to use other constructions such as the sentence below which has a similar meaning:

  • སྤུ་གུ་ཚོས་གཟབ་གཟབ་མ་བྱས་ཙང་ཤེལ་སྐོ་ཆག་བཞག “Because the children were not careful, the pane broke.”

The resultative verbs include a few intransitive volitional and transitive volitional forms. In such cases, the corresponding causative verbs have a supplementary actant that itself acts on another agent.

  • སྤུ་གུ་ཁོ་རང་གིས་ཕྱུ་པ་གོན་པ་རེད། Resultative: “The child herself put on her chuba.”
  • ཨ་མས་སྤུ་གུ་ལ་ཕྱུ་པ་སྐོན་པ་རེད། Causative: “The mother put the chuba on the child.” (ditransitive) (Note that this is a very formal register; in the conversational language, the verb གཡོགས་ would be used.)
  • རྨོ་ལགས་ལང་ཐུབ་ཀྱི་མི་འདུག Resultative: “The old lady can’t get up.”
  • ངས་རྨོ་ལགས་བསླངས་པ་ཡིན། Causative: “I helped the old lady to get up.”

Causative and resultative verbs can appear in the same sentence. The causative puts emphasis on the cause of the process and the effort of the agent in performing the action, while the resultative verb is concerned only with the result or the consequence of that action. Such constructions may therefore be translated by using the verbs “to succeed,” “to manage,” “can,” or other modal expressions.

These constructions, which frequently occur in the literary language, also appear in the spoken language.

  • བསྔགས་པས་ཆར་པ་ཕབ་ནས་དངོས་ནས་བབས་སོང་ང་། “After the ngakpa had (performed a ritual) to make rain fall, rain did indeed fall!”
  • རས་འདི་དཔེ་ཀྲོག་མཁྲགས་པོ་འདུག ག་ཚད་དབྲལ་ནའི་རལ་གྱི་མི་འདུག “This cloth is very strong, I can’t tear it!” (Literally: “However much I [try to] tear it, it won’t tear.”)

The following examples are taken from literary texts:

  • མ་བྲིས་སེམས་ཀྱི་རི་མོ་སུབ་ཀྱང་ཟུབ་རྒྱུ་མི་འདུག “Even if one rubs, one cannot rub out the undrawn lines on the heart.” (Causative: སུབ་; Resultative: ཟུབ་)
  • ནང་རང་སེམས་བཟུང་བས་མ་ཟིན་ན་ཕྱི་གཞན་ལུས་བཟུང་བས་ཅི་ལ་ཕེན། “If you try to control your own mind inside and you don’t succeed, then what’s the use of catching somebody else’s body outside.” (Causative: བཟུང་; Resultative: ཟིན་)
  • ཁོང་གི་མན་ཌལ་གྱི་སྟེང་ན་གཡུ་ཞིག་ཡོད་པ་བྱི་བ་ཞིག་གིས་བཏེག་པས་མ་ཐེག་པ་ལ། “(Once), he (saw) a mouse trying to move a turquoise that was on his maṇḍala. But the mouse could not lift the jewel on its own, so…” (Causative: བཏེག་; Resultative: ཐེག་)

 

[1] Many of the causative verbs were formed by a morpheme ས attached to the verb. This is still visible in the Tibetan orthography: འཁོལ་ (resultative), སྐོལ་ (causative); ཉལ་ (resultative), སྙལ་ (causative); ལང་ (resultative), སླང་ (causative); འཁོར་ (resultative), སྐོར་ (causative), etc.
